heisig_chinese_memo: The gay parade looks astonishing, lush with overgrown flowers.
heisig_story: The sense of the key word overgrown is of something growing luxuriously, though not necessarily in excess - in this case a whole parade of weeds (outcast flowers). By way of exception, the flowers take their normal place over the enclosure.

год дракона
koohiiStory1: The gay parade looks astonishing, as if overgrown with flowers.
koohiiStory2: When your garden gets OVERGROWN, it´s like the plants are mocking you. Here, you can see the roses actually parading around the yard, wilfully choking out the other, more docile plants. Then they actually go and parade down the street!
jp_example_words: 茂る(しげる): grow thick, luxuriate, be luxurious
WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: You take flowers down a slide to a drunkard that you picked from your luxuriant garden. You picked the flowers from the luxuriant garden, not the drunkard, mind you. Also the drunkard has a cane, but not flowers. That’s why you picked some from your luxuriant garden and slid down your cool slide. Now the drunkard has a cane and some flowers.
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: Imagine picking these flowers from your luxuriant garden then shooting down the slide. There are so many flowers that you are simply overwhelmed by their aroma. Now hand your flowers to the drunkard and watch his face light up as he excitedly thanks you for the gift.
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: The drunkard is so happy to receive flowers from your luxuriant garden that he begins to moan (も) with pleasure. The moans are getting louder and more erotic. You’re kind of creeped out. You really want him to stop moaning.
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Hear the drunkard moan as he rubs the flowers all over his body. You’re really weirded out. This is the last time you give him flowers from your luxuriant garden, that’s for sure.
Kanshudo_mnemonic: five (戊) lots of grass (艹) = overgrown
chinese_mnemonics_deck__story: The gay parade looks astonishing, lush with overgrown flowers.
humanum_full_description_en:
From the sound of "艸" and " E ", the original meaning is prosperous vegetation. "Shuowen": "Congfu is abundant. Congcai, Wusheng." "Poetry·Daya·Shengmin": "Fujue is rich in grass, planted yellow and mao." Kong Yingdashu: "Since the grass is gone, it is planted here. Those who flourish in yellow are called the valley of millet."

" Mao " can be extended to prosperous and abundant. "Book of Yi Zhou‧ Ji Gong": "The emperor changed the order of the great Yin, the king of Uyghur will receive it, the king of Uyghur will kill it, and the Xianmao will make a contribution."

" Mao " can also mean excellence and excellence. "Poetry‧Qifeng‧Huan": "The son is so prosperous, and I am in the same way as I am."

" Mao " also means beauty. The Southern Song Dynasty Liu Yiqing's "Shi Shuo Xin Yu-Rong Zhi": "Some people sigh Wang Gong Xing Mao Zhe Yun: Zhuozhu is like a spring moon willow."
humanum_short_description_en: From the sound of "艸" and " W ", the original meaning is prosperous vegetation.
humanum_full_description:
從「艸」，「戊」聲，本義為草木繁盛。《說文》：「艸豐盛。从艸，戊聲。」 《詩‧大雅‧生民》：「茀厥豐草，種之黃茂。」孔穎達疏：「既去其草，於此地種之以黃色而茂盛者，謂黍稷之穀也。」

　　「茂」可引申為昌盛、豐碩。《逸周書‧祭公》：「皇天改大殷之命，維文王受之，維武王剋之，咸茂厥功。」

　　「茂」也可表示優秀、卓越。《詩‧齊風‧還》：「子之茂兮，遭我乎峱之道兮。」

　　「茂」還表示美好。南朝宋劉義慶《世說新語‧容止》：「有人歎王恭形茂者云：濯濯如春月柳。」
humanum_short_description: 從「艸」，「戊」聲，本義為草木繁盛。

茂る(しげる): grow thick, luxuriate, be luxurious

從「 艸 」，「 戊 」聲，本義為草木繁盛。《說文》：「艸豐盛。从艸，戊聲。」 《詩‧大雅‧生民》：「茀厥豐草，種之黃茂。」孔穎達疏：「既去其草，於此地種之以黃色而茂盛者，謂黍稷之穀也。」 「 茂 」可引申為昌盛、豐碩。《逸周書‧祭公》：「皇天改大殷之命，維文王受之，維武王剋之，咸茂厥功。」 「 茂 」也可表示優秀、卓越。《詩‧齊風‧還》：「子之茂兮，遭我乎峱之道兮。」 「 茂 」還表示美好。南朝宋劉義慶《世說新語‧容止》：「有人歎王恭形茂者云：濯濯如春月柳。」
From the sound of " 艸" and " E", the original meaning is prosperous vegetation. "Shuowen": "Congfu is abundant. Congcai, Wusheng." "Poetry·Daya·Shengmin": "Fujue is rich in grass, planted yellow and mao." Kong Yingdashu: "Since the grass is gone, it is planted here. Those who flourish in yellow are called the valley of millet." " Mao" can be extended to prosperous and abundant. "Book of Yi Zhou‧ Ji Gong": "The emperor changed the order of the great Yin, the king of Uyghur will receive it, the king of Uyghur will kill it, and the Xianmao will make a contribution." " Mao" can also mean excellence and excellence. "Poetry‧Qifeng‧Huan": "The son is so prosperous, and I am in the same way as I am." " Mao" also means beauty. The Southern Song Dynasty Liu Yiqing's "Shi Shuo Xin Yu-Rong Zhi": "Some people sigh Wang Gong Xing Mao Zhe Yun: Zhuozhu is like a spring moon willow."

茂字的基本解释

茂
mào
草木旺盛：茂盛。丰茂。
美，有才德：茂士。茂才（即“秀才”）。
有机化合物，环戊间二烯的简称。无色液体，用来制农药、塑料等。
古同“懋”，勉。

茂字的起名意思

：本义为草木繁盛，繁盛、茂盛。也指美、有才德，如茂士，茂才。

Mao
Basic explanation of words
Mao
mào
Vigorous vegetation: lush. Abundance.
Beauty, talent: Mao Shi. Mao Cai (ie "Xiu Cai").
Organic compound, short for cyclopentadiene. Colorless liquid, used to make pesticides, plastics, etc.
Gu Tong "Mao" and Mian.

Kangxi dictionary interpretation of words
Mao
Source glyph
Mao
Name meaning
: The original meaning is prosperous vegetation, prosperous and lush. It also refers to beauty and talent, such as Maoshi and Maocai.
mào
1) цветущий, пышный, густой, обильный; пышно, обильно, густо (о растениях)
茂生 пышно расти
2) прекрасный, превосходный
德茂 добродетель прекрасна
俊茂 превосходный, отличный
子之茂兮 как прекрасны Вы (в Вашем искусстве) !
3) хим. циклопентадиен
4) процветать
德音是茂 процветает (растёт) слава о Вашей добродетели
5) Мао (фамилия)
Radicals: 艹, 丿, 戈  (flowers, slide, drunkard)
Meaning Mnemonic
You take flowers down a slide to a drunkard that you picked from your luxuriant garden. You picked the flowers from the luxuriant garden, not the drunkard, mind you. Also the drunkard has a cane, but not flowers. That’s why you picked some from your luxuriant garden and slid down your cool slide. Now the drunkard has a cane and some flowers.
Imagine picking these flowers from your luxuriant garden then shooting down the slide. There are so many flowers that you are simply overwhelmed by their aroma. Now hand your flowers to the drunkard and watch his face light up as he excitedly thanks you for the gift.
Reading Mnemonic
The drunkard is so happy to receive flowers from your luxuriant garden that he begins to moan (も) with pleasure. The moans are getting louder and more erotic. You’re kind of creeped out. You really want him to stop moaning.
Hear the drunkard moan as he rubs the flowers all over his body. You’re really weirded out. This is the last time you give him flowers from your luxuriant garden, that’s for sure.
